thread.title: 2,500 jobs could go next week with electronics retailer Maplin set to close

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: 2,500 jobs could go next week with electronics retailer Maplin set to close
text:
Business 2,500 jobs could go next week with electronics retailer Maplin set to close No buyer has been found for the struggling electrical chain and it is thought administrators might start closing stores within days Share Outside a Maplin store (Image: Birmingham Mail) Share Get business   Thank you for subscribing!   
Fears are growing for the fate of 2,500 Maplin workers as hopes of finding a buyer for the stricken electronics chain fade and stores set to begin closing over the coming weeks. 
The retailer, owned by private equity firm Rutland Partners, appointed PwC to oversee an administration at the end of February after rescue attempts failed. 
Maplin has 217 stores in the UK, including outlets in Newcastle, Gateshead, Cramlington, Durham and Middlesbrough. 
PwC is attempting to find a buyer for the group, but it is understood that no credible offer has materialised. 
It is thought that, if a white knight fails to emerge in the coming days, store closures could be announced as soon as next week. 
The axe has already been swung on 129 jobs at the firm’s head offices in London and Rotherham, and thousands more are now expected to be made redundant. Read More More than 11,000 restaurants in trouble as 'perfect storm' hits dining sector 
When Maplin went bust last month, it became the second retailer to collapse into administration in one day following the failure of Toys R Us, which is shutting all 100 of its UK stores. 
Maplin chief executive Graham Harris said at the time that the retailer had been struggling to mitigate the impact of the pound’s devaluation since the Brexit vote, along with a weak consumer environment and the withdrawal of credit insurance. 
It comes in a dismal first quarter for the UK high street, with Carpetright also announcing on Wednesday the prospect of store closures, and Moss Bros and Mothercare also in the doldrums. Read More 45 jobs at risk in Newcastle after engineering firm hit by Carillion's demise 
Earlier this week New Look agreed a restructuring plan with creditors which will see it shut 60 stores, resulting in the loss of up to 980 jobs. 
A host of restaurant chains - including outlets run by celebrity chef Jamie Oliver, Prezzo and burger chain Byron - are also planning to shut hundreds of branches. Like us on Facebook
